awd_abstract_narration:
The purpose of this project is to plan and organize the 2019 National Science Foundation (NSF) Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) Principal Investigator (PI) Meeting. This meeting convenes all PIs of the NSF CPS Program for the ninth time since the program began. The PI Meeting is to take place on November 21-22, 2019 in Alexandria, Virginia. The PI meeting is an annual opportunity for NSF-sponsored CPS researchers, industry representatives, and Federal agency representatives to gather and review new CPS developments, identify new and emerging applications, and to discuss technology gaps and barriers. The program agenda is community-driven and includes presentations (oral and poster) from PIs, reports of past year program activities, and showcase/pitch new CPS innovations and results.

The annual PI Meeting serves as the only opportunity where the NSF-funded CPS Principal Investigators meet to share their research, discuss new research opportunities and challenges, and explore new ideas and partnerships for future work. Furthermore, the PI meeting is also an opportunity for the academic research community to interact with industry entities and government agencies with vested interest in CPS research and development. The PI Meeting is a forum for sharing ideas across the CPS community. It has played a major role in growing the community across a broad range of sectors and technologies, and performing outreach to others who have interest in learning about the program and participating as future proposers, transition partners, or sponsors. The 2018 PI meeting will feature lightning talks from researchers, poster sessions, special topic workshops, demonstrations and keynotes from leaders in the research community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of the tenth annual CPS PI Meeting held Wednesday, November 20 (arrival night) – Thursday November 21 & Friday, November 22, 2019 (meeting days) at the Crystal Gateway Marriott in Arlington, Virginia, was to organize the end-to-end planning and organization of the meeting. The meeting was attended by 511 stakeholders from academia, industry, and Federal agencies, foreign institutions, independent research labs, and non-profit organizations for this engaging two-day agenda, which was the largest attendance for any CPS PI Meeting to date. Of these 511 attendees, 476 comprised Lead PIs, PIs, and Co-PIs. The goal of CPS PI Meetings is to assemble on annual basis the hundreds of CPS PIs whose CPS research is supported by NSF to discuss new developments and progress of the diverse research that spans a broad spectrum of domain sectors, including agriculture, climate change, energy, the environment, healthcare, and transportation, among many other sectors; to identify new, emerging applications; to discuss technology gaps and barriers; and brainstorm future research directions. The program of the meeting included presentations about projects funded by NSF and other CPS agencies, keynotes, panels, discussion groups, and poster & demonstration sessions.

The program of the meeting included four distinguished keynote presenters whose combined talks covered diverse foundational and domain CPS research topics. Dr. Paul Eremenko (most recently the former Chief CTO of Airbus and United Technologies Corporation) provided the day one morning keynote on the topic of Toward the Model-Based Digital Thread: The Past, Present, and Future of Design Methods for Complex Systems, and Dr. Raquel Urtasun (Chief Scientist, Uber ATG, head of Uber ATG Toronto, and Associate Professor at the University of Toronto) spoke on the topic of A Future with Affordable Self-Driving Vehicles. On day two, the morning keynote was delivered by Dr. Ethan Jackson (Senior Director and Principal Researcher at Microsoft Healthcare) and Dr. Jonathan Weintroub (Harvard) provided the afternoon keynote on the topic of Instrumentation and Technology Supporting the Event Horizon Telescope.

CPS PIs were directly involved in key elements of the program including:

  • leading discussions in the form of six mini workshops that covered the topics of Agriculture CPS, Autonomous Vehicles, Safe Autonomy, CPS Education, Medical CPS, and Smart and Connected Communities
  • giving project talks via a CPS Frontiers Projects panel and 126 lightning talks about the thrust and progress of their research
  • showcasing their research via 255 project posters and 23 project demonstration presentations
  • interacting and networking directly with each other, Government program managers, and other stakeholders during this year’s Woman and Under-Represented Minorities Special Interest Networking Luncheon

The meeting was attended by Dr. Damian Dudek, a distinguished guest from the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG)/[i.e., German Research Foundation] – the NSF counterpart agency. In December 2018, NSF/CISE and the DFG embarked on a collaborative effort to establish the foundation for supporting joint research in the area of CPS research.

Other Federal agencies supporting the 2019 CPS PI Meeting event included the Department of Homeland Security, the National Institutes of Health, the U.S. Department of Agriculture, and the U.S. Department of Transportation.

All public artifacts, including a meeting webcast, website Urls, speaker presentations, position papers, the meeting program, meeting participant lists, and meeting organizers have been disseminated to communities of interest via the public 2019 CPS PI Meeting website which can be found at https://cps-vo.org/group/cps-pimtg19.

All program committee pre-meeting working documents are stored on the private program committee working group site at https://cps-vo.org/group/cps-pimtg19-pc and are only available to the program committee members.

Pre-meeting planning for this second PI Meeting took place over a nine-month calendar period in conjunction with members of the Vanderbilt ISIS CPS VO team and NSF CISE CPS PDs, and Technical Program lead from Duke University. Project tasks concluded with post-meeting archiving of content on the PI Meeting website and other administrative wrap-ups over a three-month period.

 


Last Modified: 10/13/2021
Modified by: Frankie King
